articles.headline: Once Wary, Apple Warms Up to Business Market
articles.snippet: Apple, long resolute in its catering to consumers, is suddenly finding corporations becoming big customers.
articles.abstract: Apple, long resolute in its catering to consumers, is suddenly finding corporations becoming big customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Steven P. Jobs never cared much for selling Apple products to big businesses.

articles.headline: F.H.A. Audit Sees Possible Bailout Need
articles.snippet: A report says a further decline in the housing market could drain reserves, but the Federal Housing Administration’s head sees little cause for concern.
articles.abstract: A report says a further decline in the housing market could drain reserves, but the Federal Housing Administration’s head sees little cause for concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chances are nearly 50 percent that the Federal Housing Administration will need a bailout next year if the housing market deteriorates further, the agency’s independent auditor said in a report released Tuesday.

articles.headline: Novelist Fights the Tide by Opening a Bookstore
articles.snippet: Nashville’s reading faithful have found a savior in Ann Patchett, the best-selling author, whose Parnassus Books will open Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Nashville’s reading faithful have found a savior in Ann Patchett, the best-selling author, whose Parnassus Books will open Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — After a beloved local bookstore closed here last December and another store was lost to the Borders bankruptcy, this city once known as the Athens of the South, rich in cultural tradition and home to Vanderbilt University, became nearly barren of bookstores.

articles.headline: Arizonans Vie to Claim Cross-Cultural Fried Food
articles.snippet: The savory chimichanga has drawn such a following that residents want to nominate it as the state’s official food.
articles.abstract: The savory chimichanga has drawn such a following that residents want to nominate it as the state’s official food.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Florida has its key lime pie, Idaho its potatoes and Georgia favors grits as its official state food. Arizona, hungry to lay claim to a state food of its own, is circling the chimichanga.

articles.headline: Bell Ringers Go Digital This Season
articles.snippet: With fewer and fewer shoppers carrying cash, the Salvation Army’s seasonal bell ringers will begin accepting digital donations as part of its Red Kettle Campaign.
articles.abstract: With fewer and fewer shoppers carrying cash, the Salvation Army’s seasonal bell ringers will begin accepting digital donations as part of its Red Kettle Campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon, the holiday sounds of coins clinking into red kettles may disappear, replaced by the silence of a credit card swipe.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Spared in War, Libya’s Oil Flow Is Surging Back
articles.snippet: Libya’s interim government predicts output will be back to preconflict levels by June. International analysts are not as optimistic.
articles.abstract: Libya’s interim government predicts output will be back to preconflict levels by June. International analysts are not as optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAWIYAH, Libya — The bullet holes in the oil tanks have been patched, the damaged backup generator is being repaired, and most important, the pipeline that feeds the giant oil refinery here has been reopened.

articles.headline: A U.S. Marine Base for Australia Irritates China
articles.snippet: President Obama said the move to base 2,500 Marines in Australia is not intended to isolate China, but it is an unmistakable sign that the United States has grown more wary of its intentions.
articles.abstract: President Obama said the move to base 2,500 Marines in Australia is not intended to isolate China, but it is an unmistakable sign that the United States has grown more wary of its intentions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — President Obama announced Wednesday that the United States planned to deploy 2,500 Marines in Australia to shore up alliances in Asia, but the move prompted a sharp response from Beijing, which accused Mr. Obama of escalating military tensions in the region.
